docs.lead_paragraph: My sister-in-law was healthy one day, but not the next.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Andrea Louise Campbell recounts story of her uninsured sister, who became a quadriplegic at age 32 after a devastating car accident; says that she will now be thrust into the financially crippling world of state-sponsored Medicaid programs; offers story as a corrective to arguments by conservative Supreme Court justices who are skeptical of the merits of forcing young, healthy people to buy insurance.
docs.snippet: My sister-in-law was healthy one day, but not the next.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: At the Brooklyn Brainery, a hipster schoolhouse started by a pair of underemployed polymaths, students can learn abstruse subjects like the secret lives of bacteria.
docs.abstract: Brooklyn Brainery, a hipster schoolhouse started by a pair of underemployed polymaths, offers low-cost courses on eclectic subjects popular with recent college grads.
docs.snippet: At the Brooklyn Brainery, a hipster schoolhouse started by a pair of underemployed polymaths, students can learn abstruse subjects like the secret lives of bacteria.

docs.lead_paragraph: Only about 30 percent of family businesses survive beyond the founder’s generation. Those that do have a willingness to reinvent, a focus on succession and an openness to outside help.

headline.seo: How Some Beat the Odds to Keep Family Businesses Healthy
headline.main: Family Businesses Learn to Adapt to Keep Thriving
headline.print_headline: Family Businesses Learn to Adapt To Keep Thriving

docs.abstract: Only about 30 percent of family businesses survive beyond the founder’s generation, and just 12 percent make it to a third; those that do have a willingness to reinvent, a focus on succession and an openness to outside help.
docs.snippet: Only about 30 percent of family businesses survive beyond the founder’s generation. Those that do have a willingness to reinvent, a focus on succession and an openness to outside help.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney said that President Obama’s recent remarks call “his candor into serious question.”

headline.seo: Romney Says Obama Is Hiding His True Policy Aims
headline.main: Romney Says Obama Hides His Agenda
headline.print_headline: Romney Says Obama Is Hiding His True Policy Aims

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of health care habits found that patients are still struggling to pay for medical care despite the economic recovery.

headline.seo: Americans Struggle With Medical Care Despite Economic Recovery
headline.main: Americans Cutting Back on Drugs and Doctor Visits
headline.print_headline: Americans Cutting Back on Drugs and Doctor Visits

docs.abstract: IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics reports that patients cut back on prescription drugs and doctor visits in 2011, a sign that many Americans are still struggling to pay for health care despite the economic recovery; notes that prescriptions fell by 1.1 percent compared with 2010, and doctor visits fell by 4.7 percent.
docs.snippet: A study of health care habits found that patients are still struggling to pay for medical care despite the economic recovery.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on March 28 about the requirement that most Massachusetts residents have health insurance gave an incomplete account of the options that Wayde Lodor, an independent consultant from Leominster, had for buying health coverage. While Mr. Lodor, after researching several plans, estimated he would have to spend at least $1,200 a month to insure himself and his daughter, he could in fact have bought coverage through the state's insurance exchange for significantly less.

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of sharp debate over efforts to curb access to abortion and contraception, women's rights activists say they are raising record amounts of money for the autumn election campaign.

headline.main: U.S. Culture War With Women at Its Center
headline.print_headline: U.S. Culture War With Women at Its Center

docs.snippet: After months of sharp debate over efforts to curb access to abortion and contraception, women's rights activists say they are raising record amounts of money for the autumn election campaign.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recommendations on 45 common procedures, likely to alter standards of hospital care, represent an acknowledgment by doctors that many profitable treatments are performed unnecessarily.

headline.seo: Doctor Panels Urge Fewer Routine Tests
headline.main: Doctor Panels Recommend Fewer Tests for Patients
headline.print_headline: Doctor Panels Recommend Fewer Tests For Patients

docs.abstract: Medical specialty boards plan to recommend that doctors perform 45 common tests and procedures less often, and to urge patients to question these services if they are offered; recommendations represent frank acknowledgment by doctors that many profitable treatments are performed unnecessarily but change of heart also reflects changes in the health care marketplace.
docs.snippet: The recommendations on 45 common procedures, likely to alter standards of hospital care, represent an acknowledgment by doctors that many profitable treatments are performed unnecessarily.

docs.lead_paragraph: Shielded behind their white marble pillars, the black robes take a red brush to history.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column criticizes the conservative members of the Supreme Court; accuses them of substituting political motives for legal reasoning during oral arguments over the constitutionality of the health care reform law.
docs.snippet: Shielded behind their white marble pillars, the black robes take a red brush to history.
